story: NewsTerried boy, , has separation anxiety after Momo challenge Peppa Pig threatMum Sophie Giblin became worried after his son suffered a sudden bout of separation anxietyShareByMatt Roper:,  FEB NewsMum-of-three Sophie with her five-year-old son, Harry"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A mum has told how her five-year-old son suffered severe separation anxiety after being threatened by the sick Momo character while watching episodes of Peppa Pig .Sophie Giblin said that after talking about the terrying bulging-eyed doll with son Harry one day after school he burst in to tears, saying she had told him she would kill his family. And the mum-of-three, from Withernsea, near Hull, was horried to hear from her youngest son, aged just three, that the children’s videos he’d been watching on YouTube were full of blood and gore. Speaking to , Sophie, , said she had become worried about Harry after he had suddenly started to become distressed when he had to leave her, even dropping out of after-school activities. She said: “For the past few weeks he has been terried to leave my side.   “It got so bad he wouldn’t let go of the car door when it came to go to school, sobbing. He dropped out of all of his after-school clubs. He didnt want to be away from me. “I have a one-year-old daughter who is disabled, and we’ve been going to sibling support, so I took him to talk about it. We didn’t know what might have caused him to be so frightened to be away from me.” Sophie said she had asked her two sons, aged five and three, where they had heard of Momo after becoming away of the sick online ‘suicide game’, but they always denied knowing about it. Alerts have been issued about the so-called Momo challenge, which has been linked to several child deaths. Momo - a terrying bug-eyed doll with straggly hair and a devilish grin - reportedly encourages children to harm themselves and even to take their own lives. Sophie said: “Obviously I never showed Harry the picture, and when he kept saying, ‘no, I haven’t heard of it’, I believed him. “Then on Tuesday night, in the middle of a conversation, he started randomly telling me what the picture looked like. “I said to him, how do you know what it looks likeyou’ve never seen it, and he just burst into tears and was terried. “He just kept saying that he didn’t want to talk about it. I had to convince him that no-one would get hurthe told me.   “So he sat down and told me he’d seen Momo several times, while watching YouTube videos. He watches videos of Peppa Pig, and people playing Minecraft and Roblox, just normal videos I thought weren’t at all harmful. And he said Momo just comes up in the middle of it. “He told me it was a secret, and that the videos told him he was a naughty boy, and not to tell me becausethey did it would hurt his family members. “After he had spoken to me he wouldn’t leave my side, just like he had been these last few weeks. He was really scared.” Sophie said she got another shock when she told her other, younger son that he could no longer watch his favourite Peppa Pig videos on YouTube. She said: “He said, ‘what the red ones  The ones with knives and blood ’ I didn’t know there were Peppa Pig videos out there showing blood and violence. I was horried. “I had to convince him that no-one would get hurthe spoke to me. He said Momo turned up in the middle of the videos he watches, Peppa Pig and people playing Minecraft and Roblox. “He told me it was a secret and that she’d told him she would hurt his familyhe told us. “It made me really upset that I’d allowed him to see these things, I was shook up because I’d never seen him so frightened.”  Sophie said: “I had a lump in my throat when I heard that. It made me feel really upset that I’d allowed them to see these things, just to think what it was doing to their heads. “I was shook up to see my son so frightened. It was so hard to hear. I’m sure that these things are behind his bout of separation anxiety. He was terried of losing me.” Other parents have revealed how their own children have been left terried and in tears after being targetted by Momo. KirbiLeigh Hecker told how she had caught her daughter Layla searching for her paracetamol tablets, saying Momo had told her thatshe didn’t swallow  she would kill her parents.Mum-of-two KirbiLeigh, from Hartlepool, wrote on Facebook : “I’m absolutely mortied.“I asked them when they got in from school, do they know anyone called Momo off YouTube, they instantly started crying. After Layla calmed down I asked her what does it do.” She posted a video of their conversation, as her daughter tells her “She kills people, mums and dads. “If we do not listen she kills our parents saying they have to take paracetamol for our parents to live.” And Elli Spicer told on Facebook how her five-year-old son Ronnie had threatened to stab his classmates after watching videos featuring the evil doll. The mum-of-two from Dover, Kent, said she was called into his school around four weeks ago after he threatened two other kids, but has since discovered he had been exposed to Momo without her knowledge. She wrote: “I’m absolutely devastated. “In the car on the way home from school yesterday, I asked Honey or Ronniethey knew what ‘Momo’ meant  “Honey instantly looked in my mirror at me and went Eww Mum I have she’s got a smile like joker  big scary eyes - Ronnie just sat there staring at me. Honey said she’d never watched a video of this sick freak telling her to do bad or dangerous things but that she’s popped up in loads of innocent kids videos on YouTube, where her neck twists round or she’ll walk across the screen! “Ron refused to tell me at first not taking his eyes off me in the mirror and was completely in denial about ever seeing this ugly c***. “He’s been wetting the bed and he’s been coming into my bedroom early hours because of scary dreams! I am absolutely gutted, I honestly thought my children were quite sheltered.” Schools across the country have started warning parents to be extra vigilant over the disturbing phenomenon which is designed to avoid detection by adults. And police today issued a warning about the “suicide game”, which they claim is being used by hackers to harvest information from children.

story: NewsKiller childminder called mum so she could hear her screaming baby die in agonyKaty Fernando said she could hear her daughter Bellas screams in the background of a phone call to Nydia Carillo-Maldonado in Stamford, Connecticut, USAShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsNydia Carillo-Maldonado waited for three hours to call an ambulance as baby Bella screamed in pain"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA twisted babysitter called a mother to let her hear her two-month-old daughter screaming in pain as she died. Katy Redondo and her husband Fernando almost did not attend -year-old Carillo-Maldonado’s sentencing, because they are furious with Carillo-Maldonado’s sentence of just three and a half years over the July  crime. The parentsattorney Mark Sherman said: Theyre appalled that there was no contrition, no remorse, no Im sorry, Theyre grateful to the police, states attorney, for working on this case for three years.It was a challenging case because there was no acceptance of responsibility by the defendant. story: NewsBrutal message left for boss as team of fast food workers all quit at same timeA group of fast food workers have all walked out on their jobs at once, leaving behind a very brutal letter for their bossesShareCommentsByCourtney PochinAudience Writer:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsStaff have aired their views on a management change at Sonic Drive-In in Circleville"Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailCustomers at a fast food restaurant in Circleville, Ohio got a surprise when they went to grab a burger and fries. story: NewsIndia building , bunkers along Pakistan border as shelling continuesIndia and Pakistan both claim to have shot down planes in an aerial engagement over the skies of the disputed Kashmir regionShareCommentsByTom DavidsonOnline Reporter:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news video captured-indian-pilot-claims-rescued-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailMore than , bunkers are being built by India along the Pakistan border as tensions remain high in the region. The bunkers, suitable for families, are being built along Indias border with Pakistan in Jammu and Kashmir state. On Tuesday evening, Pakistan used heavy calibre weapons to shell  to  places along the Indian side of the de facto border that ides Kashmir, a spokesman for the Indian defence forces said. That had created panic among people, said Rahul Yadav, the deputy commissioner of the Poonch district, a remote area of the Indian state that faced some of the attacks. The new shelters, which were planned before this weeks spike in tensions, are supposed to reduce that fear and prevent people from having to flee when the shelling begins. There have been frequent exchanges of fire along the actual and de facto borders in recent months, but Tuesdays firing marked a major escalation after India carried out an air strike on what it said was a training camp run by an Islamist militant group in Pakistan.   India was responding to a suicide car bombing claimed by a member of the group that killed  Indian paramilitary police in Kashmir almost two weeks ago. story: NewsSick gangs who kidnap kids to sell as sex slaves - with bonuses for pretty onesThe Philippines is fast becoming one of the abduction capitals of the world with young children the latest victimsShareCommentsByJane Lavender:,  FEB Newsthis.style.displaynone"Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news world-news video woman-reveals-how-gangs-kidnap-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:, combinedPrompt :true, subsets :[,,,,,],bundledCss:,swipeNavigation.endpoint:https:mab.data.tm-awx pwa-swipe,mvtTests.enable:true,swipeNavigation:true""Get the biggest daily news stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Playing in front of her home, a happy -year-old had no clue she had been targeted by a sick gang hell bent on snatching youngsters fom the streets.As she enjoyed herself in the sunshine a shadow cast itself across her game. Lilibeth Bustamante asked the youngster to go with her to a shop and it was only when a neighbour stepped in to intervene as the woman grabbed the little girls arm that she was saved. The terrying incident took place in Paranaque City, the Philippines, on February .And this latest attempted abduction is one of the reasons the country is becoming known as one of the kidnapping capitals of the world.  In one year alone  people were abducted and both the US and British embassies have warned tourists travelling to the Philippines to be vigilent in light of the kidnapping threat.Bustamante was arrested after the concerned neighbour called the police and she told officers the terrying way the kidnapping gangs operate.The gangs snatch children and then sell them on the black market to become sex slaves. Bustamante, who says she was paid just pound: to carry out the abduction, claimed she worked with other women to kidnap children from the streets. She said: I only take them, they sell. They only give me one thousand pesos. I send it to my family in Mindoro.   The alleged kidnapper then claimed the gang would sell the children - both boys and girls - to foreign buyers who would often have sex with the youngsters while streaming it online anc charging people to watch. The children sell for as little as pound,. Bustamante said: We have a quota of two children per week. Our target age is -years-old and above. They require us to take good-looking children. They get , to , pesos depending on their looks. My cut is , pesos. Bustamante said that she had taken dozens of children since she joined the gang last year.  She added: We operate inManila and nearby towns. We dont stop until we reach our quota. Rudy Dimson , from the Parantildeaque Police Women and Children Protection Desk said: We are currently investigating the case. We want to look for other victims of this group. We urge the parents with missing children to come here. Several days after Bustamante was detained, police arrested a second woman after she was caught allegedly trying to abduct a young girl.  Locals surrounded her and called police who arrested her on suspicion of attempted child abduction in Batasan Hills district of Quezon City inManila.  And children are not the only victims of the kidnapping gangs. Militant groups are also targeted wealthy Filipinos as well as visitors. In June last year the New Peoples Army abducted a soldier while the militant Abu Sayyaf Groupsnatched the relatives of one of the countrys politicians. The most common place for tourists to be kidnapped is in the south of the country and travellers from China, Europe, Australia and America are the most likely targets. People are even being snatched from resorts and beaches by pirates.  Many of those abducted are ed uninjured but increasingly bold ransom and even terror demands mean some have been beheadedthese are not met. Last year  people believed to be membes of the ASG were convicted of kidnapping dozens of school pupils, teachers and a catholic priest in the militant groups worst ever abduction. Two of the teachers were beheaded and the priest also died while he was in captivity following the abduction in . Senior State Prosecutor Peter Ong said at the time: The persistence and determination of the court to give justice to the victims and those who were wrongfully arrested led to this decision, although it took more than one and a half decades to happen. In  a plot by the ASG to kidnap tourists on Bohol Island was foiled by authorities.  They hunted those responsible down in a dramatic speedboat chase and nine militants were killed along with three soldiers and once police officer. And last year a -year-old Japanese man was rescued by police after he was kidnapped in the Philippines. He was found in a house outside Manila. In  Kjartan Sekkingstad from Norway was kidnapped along with two Canadian men and a Filipina woman. This was one of the highest profile hostage for ransom cases in the country. Robert Hall was one of the three men kidnapped by the ASG. He spent nine months in captivity but was beheaded on September , .  Sekkingstad managed to escape when the Philippines military forces launched a surprise assault on the militant group responsible in the dead of night. The then -year-old fled through the jungles in the Sulu province to safety. But as he raced away from the scene of his captivity he stumbled across Canadian John Ridsdel, who he had become close to in their long months as hostages. Ridsdel was suffering from a broken rib so Sekkingstad carried him back to their captors. Just  hours later, Ridsdel, a father-of-two, was led away to be beheaded. Sekkingstad was finally freed almost a year after he was kidnapped.  The message from the embassy here in the UK is clear - there is a heightened risk of kidnapping in the Philippines. A spokesman said: There has been an increase in kidnapping of foreign nationals, including attacks targeting foreigners and tourists since late . Terrorist groups continue to plan kidnap operations against western nationals in the Philippines. However, since the ASGs leader, Isnilon Hapilon, died in October  the group has been fractured and less organised. The number of kidnappings fell last year compared to .

title: dundee announce pre contract signing of winger todd
story: Dundee have secured the summer signing of Queen of the South midfielder Josh Todd on a pre-contract deal.The -year-old impressed for the Doonhamers in the Championship as well as in their Scottish Cup victory over the Dark Blues last month.And Dens boss Jim McIntyre has moved quickly to secure the former St Mirren man on a two-year deal starting when his contract at Palmerston comes to an end this summer.Todd has scored six goals in  matches this season.Queens manager Gary Naysmith said: “I would like thank Josh for his efforts and contribution since joining the club.#He is a very talented player who has been great for us, it is disappointing to lose someone of his quality but that’s football.#We wouldn’t stand in the way of anyone who has the chance to move to a higher level, so he goes with our best wishes.#He is still with us for a wee while yet and, hopefully, he canfrom injury and play his part in helping us reach the play-offs.”

title: gordon forrest says dundee united fans vital in championship promotion push
story: Dundee United fans have been told they’re not just appreciated, they’ll be vital as the Championship promotion race reaches its climax.That’s the view of Tangerines assistant boss Gordon Forrest, who admits since ing to Scottish football last month he’s been blown away by the level of support Arabs give their team.Well over , headed for Falkirk on Saturday and, despite a small travelling support expected and the top two in the ision meeting in Dingwall, tonight’s clash with Inverness Caley Thistle at Tannadice will boast the biggest turnout in the second tier.While those kind of crowds can have a positive effect on the opposition, Gordon believes the positives of being the best-supported team in the ision easily outweigh any negatives.“The fans have been absolutely magnicent, particularly in the away games,” said the former Vancouver Whitecaps coach.“When the players are coming out for their warm-up, during the game, you can see the stands are packed. The fans are singing, they’re cheering and it just makes a massive dference for the players.“When we go back to Tannadice the noise levels there have been great. We appreciate it as a club and I know the players do.“When we play against teams they do pick up to their maximum in terms of their performance, they raise their game a little bit but it helps us in that push to pick up the points in the run-in.”Tonight, United will be without defender Freddy Frans after he had to come off with a groin injury at the weekend.He will see a specialist about the problem and, while United are hopeful he will not be out for too long, he has no chance of making tonight or Sunday, when the teamsto Tannadice to battle it out in the Scottish Cup quarter-finals.Rachid Bouhenna came on for Frans then had to go off late on with a facial injury, but could be OK.“Freddy is probably looking at a longer time out. In terms of finer detail and the number of days or weeks it’s hard to say just now,” added Gordon.“With Rachid, there was a lot of blood and a cut on the nose. You’ve got to be careful with that. Hopefully he can be patched up and be in the mix.”

title: sponsored 2019s ultimate holiday destination
story: With stunning natural beauty, a bustling cosmopolitan vibe and some of the world’s largest sporting events on the horizon, we’ve uncovered a whole host of reasons to visit Yokohama, Japan…Just a  minute train ride from Tokyo or Haneda International Airport lies the international harbour city of Yokohama.Situated on the western coast of Tokyo Bay, Yokohama is one of Japan’s biggest cities with more than . million inhabitants. The city offers the excitement of a vibrant metropolis as well as stunning natural beauty, the combination of which makes Yokohama completely unique. Discover five reasons to get this exciting city on your travel bucket list today…Start your journey through the city in the Minato Mirai area to view Yokohama’s iconic scenery. This historic area is home to the first port which opened up to foreign trade and shipping after the Meiji Restoration in . Minato Mirai offers its most impressive and romantic views at night as the coloured lights and steel buildings create an unmissable dramatic landscape.A short walk from Minato Mirai lies Noge District, where you can enjoy a mix of delicious izakayaas well international bars and a host of entertainment including, of course, karaoke.Spend an evening wandering through the narrow streets and hopping between the many bars and locally run izakayas. Join the locals in shouting ‘Kanpai!’over a Japanese draft beer, and relax in the open-air ‘tachi-nomi’ style bars.If you want to enjoy the authenticity of Japan but without the crowds of Tokyo, Sankeien Garden is the perfect place to start. More than , square metres in size and with  unique historical buildings, this dynamic garden transforms with the dferent seasons. In spring, pink cherry blossoms bloom while in autumn, you can enjoy the beauty of the changing leaves. To complete the experience, try a matcha tea in the heart of Sankeien Garden as you admire the stunning surroundings.But, how did Yokohama come to be the international trading and harbour centre of Japan  Surprisingly the answer lies in Scotland. During the s and s, Scottish civil engineer Richard. H. Brunton visited Japan by governmental invitation in the first year of Meiji Period. Brunton built a number of lighthouses along the Japanese coast and this formed the basis for what is now the incredible Yokohama city. Today you can still can see his works of art alongside the modern skyscrapers.To retain this connected history between Scotland and Yokohama and to encourage the two places to grow together, the Scottish Government and Yokohama signed a joint declaration in July . This collaboration encompasses a number of important areas including culture and tourism, marine and subsea industries and sports and education.This year, Japan will host the Rugby World Cup with matches being held in stadiums across the country. This makes  the perfect time to visit Yokohama as the semi-final will take place at the international stadium in the city. On top of that, the Scotland team will take on Japan in a game that will be held on the th October in Yokohama.Yokohama is also the official team camp base for the Scotland and Ireland national rugby teams and the city will host the pre-game training camp for Team GB during the Tokyo  Olympic and Paralympic Games.

title: Climate action call comes to Inverness streets
story: CLIMATE change activists from the Black Isle and Inverness have shown their solidarity for school pupils across the world after the youngsters held a lsquostrikersquo to flag up ecological concerns.New group Extinction Rebellion Highlands and Islands held a stall in Inverness High Streetlast Saturday, asking passers-by to sign a petition calling for urgent action by Highland Council to do its bit to tackle the threat, amid growing worries that the planetrsquos global warming is nearing an irreversible tipping point.Organised by Black Isle activist Anne Thomas, who is also involved with Transition Black Isle, the stall attracted  signatures in the space of  minutes.The youth strike, which included Highland participants, was sparked by Swedish teenager Greta Thunberg who spoke at the last major UN Climate Change summit saying adults were not doing enough and time was running out.ldquoLots of people had been impressed by the stand the kids had taken and were keen to show their support, said Ms Thomas. ldquoThey agreed that government at all levels is not doing enough to stop dangerous levels of global warming and climate change.ldquoScientists say we have less than  years to prevent warming going over . degrees, so we need to take drastic measures now. We could be on the brink of a mass extinction like the one which wiped out the dinosaurs.ldquoThe petition asked that the Highland Council... reverse inconsistent policies and work alongside the media to communicate with residents.The petition also called on the local authority to pass a climate emergency motion to make the region carbon neutral by .Fiona Cormie who has just taken on the role of co-ordinator of the group, said they hoped to add ldquosignicantly to its number of petition signatories in the coming weeks and present them to the council.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Disaled workers getting a raw deal new report claims
story: MANY disabled people in Scotland have been ldquofrozen out of work due to their condition, according to research by disability charity Leonard Cheshire.Three out of four said they left their jobs because they had not received the support they needed to fulfil their role, and nearly one out of five who applied for a job in the past five years felt the employer had chosen not to consider them for the post because they had a disability.Kenny Shand from Inverness who found himself in this situation, said: ldquoNot everyone is treated with respect. Whether you have additional support needs or not, the system needs to be more transparent. Workplace adjustments donrsquot need to be expensive ndash they just need to be done.Stuart Robertson, director at Leonard Cheshire in Scotland, said the findings lt the lid on a ldquotough and unwelcoming employment landscape.He said: ldquoMost people with disabilities in  remain frozen out of the world of work. All of us must redouble our efforts to challenge outdated attitudes to disability and accelerate the positive change that enables everyone to thrive in the world of work.The research also suggests more than half of all managers consider the cost of workplace adjustments a barrier to employing people with disabilities.In more promising news, Leonard Cheshirersquos research found a fth of employers say they are more likely to employ someone with a disability.The charity said the latest research shows an increased awareness amongst employers of the UK Governmentrsquos Access to Work scheme giving people grant and other support based on their needs, is up to  percent in  from  percent in .But many recipients are waiting more than three months for their application to be approved and the charity wants government action.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Family remember happy and friendly teenager after tragic accident near Inverness
story: The family of a teenager killed in a road traffic collision at Dochgarroch has spoken about their "happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly".Policehave confirmed that the -year-old who died as a result of the two-vehicle collision at around .pm on Sunday night was Samuel Foster, of Lochend near Inverness.The family said: ldquoSamuel, our darling boy, was incredibly popular and had a huge circle of friends. He attended Millburn Academy before moving to Inverness College two years ago to study engineering."He also worked at the bakery at Marks and Spencer for two years and loved his motocross biking and cars.ldquoSamuel was a happy-go-lucky boy who was always happy and friendly.ldquoSamuel was the youngest of four siblings and words canrsquot express how much he will be missed by his parents Heather and Lenny, his brother David and twin sisters Samantha and Kirsty, his nephew Reuben and niece Georgie.ldquoWe would like to thank the incredible number of people who have sent us messages of sympathy ndash your kind words mean so much and are a reminder of just how popular and well-loved Samuel was."We hope he will always be remembered this way.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Highland Council investing extra in roads maintenance
story: Highland Council is hoping an additional pound. million for maintenance announced as part of this yearrsquos budget will make a ldquonoticeable dference across the region.The funding, approved as a priority area for the revenue budget, will be shared out across Highland with area committees able to decide how to prioritise it more locally.Chairman of the councilrsquos environment, development and infrastructure committee, Councillor Allan Henderson, said: ldquoWe have the most extensive network of roads in the UK and, added to this, we are faced with some of the most severe weather conditions in the Highlands.ldquoThe freeze-thaw conditions in particular cause immense damage to road surfaces and this is very evident in the past few weeks.ldquoRoad conditions are a high priority for local residents and this was very clear in our recent engagement with communities and local representatives.ldquoThe additional resource will, I hope, make a noticeable dference and can be allocated to the roads with the most urgent need of repairs, right across the Highlands.Area allocations based on road mileage and population are:Badenoch  Strathspey: pound, Caithness: pound,Inverness: pound, Lochaber: pound, Nairn: pound,Ross  Cromarty: pound,Isle of Skye: pound,Sutherland: pound,Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Historic Inverness city centre mosaics almost completed
story: FINAL measurements have been taken for the re-installation of a well-known Inverness mosaic.Restoration work to breathe le into the historic mosaics in Invernessrsquos Academy Street started in July last year.It came after Cairngorm Taverns secured an Inver-ness Townscape Heritage grant to fully restore the former AI Welders building, which is set to have a street-level bar and first-floor restaurant.It appointed conservation specialist Laing Traditional Masonryas its main contractor although the first phase of work has been handled by sub-contractor the Mosaic Restoration Company .The mosaic of welders and foundry men at work was partially taken down last year by Northamptonshire-based MRC. Mosaics have been taken to MRCrsquos factory for restoration ndash and as one of the four original mosaics was missing, the firm has used a photograph from the s to recreate the original design.MRCrsquos Gary Bricknell described it as a fascinating project for the family-run firm and he looks forward to putting the work back in place next month.ldquoItrsquos been an really interesting job, he said. ldquoEvery one of the tiles is hand-cut for these arches which are about four or five square metres. Wersquove used tens of thousands of tiles and wersquove been working on it for over six months now.Inverness Townscape Heritage Project provided a pound, grant towards the restoration of the B-listed building which is set to open in September as a showcase for Cairngorm and Loch Ness breweries.Sam Fairclf, managing director at Cairngorm Brewery which is involved with Cairngorm Taverns, said: ldquoWe are looking to showcase as much Highland produce as possible.The building was originally the head office of the Rose Street Foundry and Engineering Company and changed to AI Welders in the s.This project is the first major investment by the Inverness Townscape Heritage Project, which is a partnership regeneration project focusing on Academy Street.The refurbishment is a collaboration of funding partners including Inverness City Heritage Trust , Historic Environment Scotland and the Heritage Lottery Fund.Alison Tanner of ICHT said: ldquoThis is not just an interesting project, it is specialist restoration, repair and reinstatement work and needs to be rejoiced.ldquoIt has been years in the planning, the local public are passionate about the mosaics and the building as a whole and this work will save them for future generations.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Hotel plan for Inverness car park site
story: PLANS which would see a city centre car park transformed into a six-storey hotel have been unveiled.The pound million proposal by developer SRP Inverness Ltd was displayed to the public at the Spectrum Centre on Farraline Park, immediately next to the two-deck Rose Street car park which is earmarked as the site for the -metre high hotel.The proposal is the latest city hotel development from SRP Inverness directors Stewart Campbell and Stuart McCaffer, who were also behind the creation of the Inverness Encore Hotel, now the Pentahotel, on nearby Academy Street.Mr Campbell is confident the -bedroom L-shaped building will attract interest from a globally-known hotel brand, bringing something new to the Inverness accommodation mix.ldquoWe have worked with a number of global brands over the years, he said.ldquoInverness has massive global tourism and a lot of people, particularly global travellers, want the comfort of a well-known global brand.ldquoInverness is a strong tourism market, but therersquos been a lack of supply over the years. Other than the Travelodge on Academy Street in , there hasnrsquot been a new hotel built in Inverness since .The proposal includes a gym, three retail units within the hotel footprint and parking for  cars.Mr Campbell believes the hotel will benefit from its proximity to Inverness bus and railway stations, while any under capacity at the car park would be compensated by the nearby multi-storey car park.Mr Campbell and Mr McCaffer also own the neighbouring Rose Street Hall, which they hope to utilise for retail or restaurant use once the hotel is completed.Between the two, they also plan to construct a new bus and taxi road, replacing the footpath linking the bus station and Rose Street retail units.SRP Inverness expects to apply for planning permission in mid-April.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness College students showcase work of Highland Hospice
story: DRAMA students at Inverness College UHI have teamed up with Highland Hospice to offer insight into the patient experience of palliative care.Third year BAdrama and performance students performed Homeward Bound, a -minute play charting one couplersquos experience of end-of-le care, after being approached by the hospice.Officials at the hospice were keen to see live drama used as an educational tool to help improve the quality of palliative care and the experience of those involved.The play was performed to staff and nursing and care students at the college, with hospice representatives providing commentary to provide context and insight into the experience.It proved such a useful educational tool, the drama students have been asked to perform the play again at the NHS Highland Highland Hospice Essentials in Palliative Care Conference at Eden Court in Inverness, on March -, where it will be filmed to be used in learning.Lesley Mickel, programme leader for the drama course, said: ldquoWe were delighted to work with Highland Hospice to develop this special performance, which really highlights the human impact of late diagnosis and the importance of quality palliative care.ldquoIt was not only a challenge for our students in terms of portraying these very raw, human emotions, it also proved an extremely useful educational tool for students studying other parts of the university curriculum, with our nursing and care students gaining a much greater understanding of the issues involved.Hospice learning and development practice lead Siobhan Neylon said: ldquoIt was such an honour to work with these wonderful students on this poignant and emotive drama.ldquoThey portrayed the characters in such a dignied way.Homeward Bound was written by playwright Brian Daniels and tells the true story of Lesley and her husband Seth Goodburn, who was diagnosed with pancreatic cancer at the age of . He died just  days after diagnosis.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness MP calls for cross party approach to secure post Brexit funding
story: INVERNESS MP Drew Hendry has issued a cross-party rally cry ahead of Brexit.He has written to the Scotland spokespeople of each of the main political parties urging them to put pressure on the UK government to prevent Scotland losing out on millions of pounds in EU funding,the UK leaves the EU.Mr Hendry, the SNPs business spokeman, has called on parties to work together to ensure the UK government delivers a like-for-like replacement for vital EU development funds in the event of Brexit.Mr Hendry said: ldquoCommunities across Scotland would be hit hard by the loss of millions of pounds in vital EU fundingthe UK government drags us out of the EU against our will."The best way to protect this funding is for Scotland to remain in the EU - as we voted overwhelmingly for - butBrexit does go ahead then the UK government must commit to replacing every single penny of the funding Scotland stands to lose."It is shocking that the UK government has already broken its own word, and failed to consult on detailed plans to replace the lost EU funding and the huge benefits it brings for Scotland.ldquoIn addition to the many other benefits of our EU membership, Scotland has enjoyed huge investment in jobs, communities and infrastructure from European funds. It is vital that this investment continues like-for-like, and that the Scottish Government continues to oversee the funding so it meets Scotlands needs.ldquoAt present, groups across the country need to make decision about their future, but have no idea what sort of funding will be available after . This must not be another power grab away from the Scottish Parliament.ldquoSome of this funding helps level the playing field of regional inequality, which is stark when comparing rural areas with urban parts. The Tories must be held to account, investment levels must be matched, and clarity must be given to communities across Scotland.ldquoThe UK government cannot continue to kick this issue into the long grass and weasel out of their responsibilities. It is time for MPs and MSPs of all parties to demand that this money is protected in full and in time to give certainty to communities across Scotland."Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Inverness pupils donate money to city cycling charity
story: PUPILS at an Inverness secondary school have selected a charity which provides cycle outings for the elderly to receive pound in funding from the Young Philanthropy Initiative .The scheme is sponsored by the Aberdeen-based Wood Foundation and students in each school were asked to make presentations to fellow students and a  of judges who selected the winning team which had a chosen charity.Millburn Academy have donated their money to Cycling Without Age, Inverness ndash a charity with specially adapted bikes which takes residents from care homes and Highland Hospice on rides around the town and local countryside.Alice Munro, principal teacher of English, said the competition was a great experience for the pupils.ldquoThey invited people from ious charities to the school and went out to see the work these charities do in the local community. After their research, teams were asked to give a presentation and the judges were former staff members, the school chaplain and a police representative.ldquoThe winning charity, Cycling Without Age, is a fantastic organisation doing great work with the elderly in the community.Cycling Without Age spokesman Mick Heath said: ldquoIt began as an idea in the head of Dr Katie Walter of Cairn Medical Practice.ldquoShe recruited me to be her helper. It all began with a chance encounter in July .ldquoWe started networking and soon had a grant from HiTrans Active Travel to buy our first electric trike for taking the elderly and frail out for rides.ldquoWe were quickly joined by Dr Moira Finlayson and we three have been going at it flat out since then.The charity now has four trikes and several volunteer pilots and has taken more than  passengers on more than  rides.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Rethink on Inverness city centre revamp
story: COUNCIL officers are to go back to the drawing board amid concerns over an ambitious project which aims to transform a key area in Inverness city centre.A bold vision including wider pavements and reduced traffic speeds in Academy Street was unveiled in November at the start of a public consultation.The Accessing Inverness project aims to complement a pound million upgrade of the rail station plus a revamp of the Victorian Market and involves HiTrans, the regional transport partnership for the Highlands and Islands, Highland Council and other organisations.Although the project team wants to apply for Sustrans funding to take the project to the next stage, Inverness councillors have demanded further work, including an impact an assessment for people with disabilities.It follows concerns that removing light and sound-controlled pedestrian crossings plus making the street and pavements the same level will pose dangers to visually impaired people.Inverness Ness-side councillor Ron MacWilliam described the design and report presented to councillors as ldquoflawed and said something had to happen.ldquoNumber one is making sure people who are least able to navigate their way around the streets of Inverness are considered in any design, he said.ldquoI donrsquot think people who are blind or partially-sighted have been considered.Accessing Inverness team leader Fiona McInally stressed there was more work to be done but the deadline for the funding application was April .She said the proposed design was outline only.ldquoIt is not set in stone, she said. ldquoWe are trying to get to a position we can get a solution and go forward.Inverness Provost Helen Carmichael said people had been asking for improvements for years and there was now an opportunity which must not be missed.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Stonework to be refurbished at Invernesss Victorian Market
story: Stonework at the Academy Street entrance to Invernesss Victorian Market is to be refurbished at a cost of pound,.The sum will be coveredby grants from the Academy Street Townscape Heritage Trust andInverness Common Good Fund .The decision to push ahead with the project will mean a delay to other planned mechanical and electrical works, alongwith the installation ofnew doors at the market.pound, remains allocated towards the upgrading of shopfronts at the market, including new lighting and flooring.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: Success sees Inverness Town House tours extended
story: POPULARITY has prompted the number of guided tours of Inverness Town House to double this summer.City councillors have agreed to add two more tours each week after positive feedback.The tours were introduced in June in a move which completed a so-called cultural triangle which includes the cityrsquos museum and Inverness Castle Viewpoint.Two tours on Thursdays have been run by High Le Highlandand proved logistically and financially viable ndash making a pound. profit ndash with the additional two tours on Tuesdays starting on from May .Tours have not disrupted any business in the building and visitors have found them engaging, informative and entertaining.Inverness provost Helen Carmichael said: ldquoWell done to High Le Highland and in particular their team of guides, who helped the council create a third, new, visitor attraction in the town house, which along with the museum and art gallery and castle viewpoint have created an accessible lsquocultural trianglersquo around the Castle Wynd area.ldquoAs we move towards the redevelopment of Inverness Castle as a new lsquomust-seersquo visitor attraction, the Town House Tours will complement the tourism offering in this city centre location.HLH chief executive Ian Murray said: ldquoHigh Le Highland has been delighted to work with the council to create public access to the splendid town house and we look forward to seeing visitor numbers and tour provision increasing this summer.Thursday  Feb  : AM

title: aberdeen woman shares secret of long life on 100th birthday
story: A north-east woman celebrating her th birthday believes the secret to a long le is “being well looked after”.Centenarian Ruby Middleton, who lives at Angusfield House care home in Aberdeen, celebrated her milestone birthday yesterday.Ruby, who has lived at the home since  after leaving her lelong home on a farm near Bucksburn, admitted she does not feel , saying “it just feels like another day”.When asked how she had lived such a long le, Ruby said: “I’ve been well looked after.”She received the traditional birthday card from the Queen and enjoyed a small celebration with residents and staff.She was also greeted by the Deputy Lord Lieutenant of Aberdeen Michael Hastie and Jeremy Richardson, the chief executive of Angusfield House’s operator Brighterkind.Mr Hastie said: “It’s amazing to see these people at that age. I have been to a few th birthday celebrations but Ruby really is remarkable.“She seemed like she was really enjoying herself. It looked as though she was liking the company and it was a really special day for her.“To make it to  years old is pretty good. I know they say we are living longer these days but it is still an amazing milestone.”Mr Richardson added: “It’s lovely to be able to celebrate Ruby’s birthday with her because it is a very special occasion.“It’s great to see her looking so happy and well at .”Staff at Angusfield House said former seamstress Ruby is a popular figure with carers and residents and always maintains a positive outlook.Activities coordinator Sandra Fyfe said: “Ruby came to us in May . She is always smiling and she is a very gentle lady.“She still gets visited by her old neighbours and they always make a point of saying how nice she was.“She’s a very friendly lady and loves chatting away.“Prior to coming in she loved flower arranging and she still talks about her garden.“The fact she is still on her feet and is able to get about with her Zimmer is amazing.“She broke her hip last year and we were quite worried about her, butanything, she was back on her feet too quickly. She didn’t let it get in the way of her living le to the fullest.“She’s just lovely.”Care assistant Elaine McConnachie added: “Ruby still loves sewing and she will always pick up a needle and threadshe sees a button coming away.“It’s always lovely to see her and she always puts a smile on your face.”

title: changes in jet stream set to bring colder weather to north east

title: dancing brings light and beauty amid the grief to ardfern
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSubscribe Nowby Laura MaxwellWithin This Dust is an interpretive dance performance inspired by the most horrying incident of our time: the   terror attacks.A packed Craignish Village Hall held host to the Dundee-based Shaper Caper performance on Wednesday February .Inspired by photographs of the   fallout, choreographer Thomas Small has created a performance that has been seen to bring tears due to its beauty and the tragedy of this story. First performed in , Within This Dust has gone on to be staged all over the UK and internationally, including at the   memorial and museum.Especially inspired by Richard Drew#s unforgettable photograph, The Falling Man, Within This Dust details the experience of witness, Lisa Hood, and victim, Vince Virr, of the   attacks.The witness finds herself surrounded in dust, made of crumpled paper, and begins a grieving process of hunting through the papers, finding meaning in the words, as someone tries to tidy around her. The second act features the victim joining the witness, creating a connection that will inevitably be broken, when finally, in the third act, the victim is alone, caught between a choice of the smoke and fire within the collapsing building or the  metre drop to freedom.It was a very poignant performance, tenderly expressing the horror of the incident, perhaps now weakened due to overindulgence. When the lights came up everyone stayed where they were, perhaps a little too stunned to move. Chatter was in whispers, for respect to people who could not hear them.As the narrator of the show captured and pieced together from coverage of the attacks said, the dust has not settled, and never will. The losses of the people in the planes and buildings is still felt, and the wider western world is still wary, still learning, still recovering.Within This Dust manages to depict the horror of that day beautully, and more importantly, delicately. No easy task for a grieving world.PIC:Craignish Village Hall was full. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood amongst the #dust#. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Lisa Hood. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood collecting dust. _aWithinThisDustLisa Hood and Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustDancer, Vince Virr. _aWithinThisDustVince Virr facing the smoke, or the window. _aWithinThisDust

title: letters week 06
story: Laura MaxwellUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  We value our content, so access to our full site is  only available on subscription.Your subscription entitles you to -day-a-week access to our website, plus a full digital copy of that week#s paper to read on your pc mac or mobile device.And there#s more # your subscription includes access to digital archive copies from  onwardsSirWe would like to take this opportunity to thank all of those who have either given or offered assistance and support to my family following the fire at our home on the night of January , and a special thanks to the emergency services that attended.Anyone who was present either at the time or who has seen the remains will appreciate the level of destruction wrought upon our home and the contents within, however, as noted in this paper last week, all of us were unharmed and have been provided with accommodation nearby.The support given by friends, work and the wider community has been truly humbling, and as a family we thank you all and look forward to ing to our home, hopefully sometime next year.Thank you,Alan and Gillian Pitman, The Old Church, ArdrishaigSir,I must commend our MP Brendan O#Hara on his vision and wisdom on his recent fact-finding trip to the Faroe Islands to see first hand how The Faroese inter-connect their islands with  subsea and through mountain tunnels.This common sense approach guarantees safe connectivity   in any weather providing confident travel which is the least the people of Mid Argyll, Kintyre, Islay and Jura should expect. This area of Argyll is the most fragile in the region. The people of Argyll, businesses and visitors deserve no less.Forget the squandering of £m on unreliable, mitigation measures trying to justy a flawed decision made many years ago to use the Old Military Road as a ersion which has failed on many occasions and now has a landslip between the two roads. Forget the expensive excavation of pits by the A rather use the cuttings into the hillside to form a two lane road protected with a flow over canopy with closed outer edges at the four problems gullies. If the contractors on the present scheme can work without any road closures then the flow over canopy option would not lead to closures as many officials and some politicians claim.This is a red herring postponing #a proper solution#. When this is option is completed it will save on the expense of manning the ersion route involving - personnel and - vehicles, replacing expensive nettings, delays whilst the farmer clears his animals and collect his fees. A scandalous waste of public money. Solve The Rest Landslides and stop wasting on mitigating measures.Like Brendan O#Hara I#m neither an engineer or geologist but both of us are blessed with plain common sense. If the Faroese can build a tunnel at £.m per kilometre surely a simple open sided m canopy would cost considerably less. In  at Dawlish .km of double tracked railway and .km of sturdy seawall was built at a cost of £m in eight weeks. Why have we in Argyll after nine years, four dferent Transport Ministers and £m spent and still have no guaranteed safe passage   on The Rest and Be Thankful Follow the Argyll Advertiser#s campaign #Invest in the Rest#. Transport Minister Michael Matheson, Transport Scotland and our Government must abandon their obsession with mitigation measures and fund a permanent solution. We demand no less.Sir,Calls for assurances that the Rest and Be Thankful section of the A will be improved to resist future landslides were made during a session of Transport, Infrastructure and Connectivity questions in the Scottish Parliament.I quizzed transport secretary Michael Matheson, about what was discussed at the last meeting of the A Taskforce in November , and asked what assurances the Cabinet Secretary could give to local residents and businesses who rely on the A being open at all times.The Rest and Be Thankful was closed off for nine days in October  following the largest landslide in a decade, forcing road users to either take a major ersion, or to use the Old Military Road during certain hours of the day.A number of petitions were created during the period of the incident, including one by myself, calling for a permanent solution to the Rest and Be Thankful.The transport secretary said that the meeting was #full and frank#, and that there would be a #review of the potential for additional landslide mitigation measures at the Rest and Be Thankful#, and that this would be discussed at the next A Taskforce meeting in March .There was also a commitment that Argyll and Bute would be #prioritised# in the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.I welcome the assurances by the transport secretary that there will be a review of any additional measures for the Rest and Be Thankful, and that Argyll and Bute will receive priority at the next Strategic Transport Projects Review.Donald Cameron, MSPReserve forcesSir,Last issue#sletter raising concerns about the UK government’s proposed use of the army’s reserve force in the event of a no-deal Brexit is timely.In case anyone out there still thinks a no-deal Brexit is a good idea it’s worth noting that the legal authorityof Reserve Forces Act  allowing the Secretary of State to take this step requires him to establish that it is necessary #for the alleviation of distress or the preservation of le or property in time of disaster or apprehended disaster#.Enough said.Frances Roberts, Ardrishaig

It is the time of Lent: the old Germanic word for spring-time. Our hearts are bidden to imitate the snow-drops: to come up from the darkness, raise themselves into the sunlight, and then fill the world with gladness.Parishioners from Ardrishaig, Christ Church, Lochgilphead and Glassary are joining together this Lent to read a poem a day through the  days of Lent and then Easter week. The poems have been chosen are in a beautul book, entitled The Heart’s Time, by Janet Morley. The poems come from across the English-speaking world, over the last four centuries. One poem is set for each day, accompanied by a short explanation, a reflection, and a brief suggestion for our own thinking.Parishioners will be reading the poems at home for those who wish it there will be meetings to share thoughts and inspiration at Ardrishaig Church during the weeks of Lent and at Christ Church on Sundays. Other meetings could be arranged, formally or informally.You can order the book from Fr Simon Mackenzie by emailing dr.lachlan@zen or calling  , or directly from Argyll Book Centre. Lent begins this year on Ash Wednesday March .E.ON donated to Arrochar roof insulationVehicles used by the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team will benefit from being garaged at a more constant temperature this winter after the E.ON Energising Communities Fund paid for £, worth of insulation to be fitted at the rescue post.The volunteers making up the Arrochar Mountain Rescue Team provide search and rescue assistance throughout Strathclyde when requested by Police Scotland and can be called upon  hours a day,  days a year.  Working across all mountainous terrain and in any weather condition, they use three vehicles which are kept in the garage attached to the mountain rescue post in Arrochar which was built in .After mechanics identied condensation and corrosion as the cause of the vehicles’ increasingly frequent and expensive mechanical and electrical problems, heating was installed at the garage last year to reduce their maintenance costs and improve their reliability. It was then realised that roof insulation was necessary to lower the cost of the heating.Douglas Philp, team secretary for Arrochar Mountain Rescue, said: #As a charity, we’re totally dependent on donations, grants and volunteers. Fundraising can be a real challenge for the team, particularly as it comes on top of our primaryof providing a mountain rescue service.#

title: ayr rugby club near move
story: NewsAyr Rugby Club near move to new town centre base at Dam Park as they prepare to sell Millbrae homeThe Millbrae men, who top the Tennents Premiership, are in advanced talks to sell their Millbrae home and move to Dam Park in Ayr town centre.ShareByStuart Wilson:,  OCT NewsDam Park could play host to Ayr Rugby Club as soon as  "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailBooming Ayr Rugby Club are nearing a deal to sell their Millbrae home and move to the town centre. Plans to buy council-owned Dam Park are at an advanced stage. The club, currently top of the Tennent’s Premiership, hope the bold switch will take them to the next level. Ayr would earn a multi-million pound jackpot by hiving off their own land for housing, with builder Cala Homes believed to be preferred bidder for the site. And they plan to use part of the cash for a pound, synthetic surface to be laid at their new home. Club chiefs have spent the last year in talks over a move and hope to seal the deal soon.  If the switch is rubber-stamped by South Ayrshire Council Ayr could be playing out of Dam Park as early as . One source said: “It is the move that makes sensethe club is to continue growing. “Next season sees the start of the Super Six set-up with games to be broadcast live on television. “It is potentially a great  for Ayr and bringing the club into the heart of the town can benefit so many.” The switch would see Ayr Seaforth Athletic Club on the move to a new sporting centre planned for Craigie. And junior side Whitletts Victoria couldto the heart of their community with a revamp of the old activity complex on the cards. Ayr rugby supremo Billy McHarg said talks on the move are progressing well.  He said: “Discussions to this point have been positive. “We’re keen to work with all parties to find the right solution and one which will benefit the whole town. “We feel that Ayr Rugby Club coming into the town centre would be a big step forward.” Club members would still have to approve such a move. Ayr have been at scenic Millbrae since . Prior to that they played out of Newton Park, Dam Park, the Old Racecourse and King George V playing fields. Whitletts chairman John Dalton said: “Talks have been very positive and we are currently looking at alternative options. “The football park at Whitletts is the obvious route to go down and would represent ahome to our roots. “A lot of water is still to go under the bridge but as Ayr’s junior football club we are viewing this as a positive opportunity.” Craigie councillor Ian Cavana said: “It may be that a deal is close but nobody will be moving anywhere until the new sports centre at Craigie is up and running. “Work is due to start on that next summer and that’s when we should see real progress.” A council spokesman said: “Discussions on the future of Dam Park are ongoing.”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyr NewsAyrAyr Rugby

title: hourstons closes ayr last independent
story: NewsHourstons closes in Ayr as last independent department store shuts up shop todayThe last independent bastion of the High Street is closing today with a giant clear-out taking place.ShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB NewsLeg-end - show is over for Hourstons "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailAyr’s last independent department store closes at pm tonight – but not before a giant clear-out. General manager Linda Lawson will pay tribute to  staff, who are all losing their jobs. And absolutely everything that could earn a pound was sold – including old mannequins , fashion stands and even store room shelving. The massive clear-out included giving away box loads of coat hangers. The building closes after  years of trading after current multi-millionaire owners the Jebreel family pulled the rug. As stock was snapped up in the sale, staff turned to fixtures and fittings to sell. Eight mannequins at pound each were snapped up - and some will remain gracing town windows. The building itself is now up for sale at offers over pound, but it is impossible to think it will ever operate as a single unit again. Staff are wanting to bow out quietly and didn’t want to line-up for an official “last photo” for the Ayrshire Post. MSP John Scott described the loss to the town as a “hammer blow.” Hourstons – and then Arnotts under House of Fraser control – has been one of Ayr’s retail institutions since the s. Orcadian David Hourston first opened a shop in Kyle Street before building the present store in . On David’s death in , his sons took over the business which had become one of the largest retail drapery establishments in Scotland. Its tearooms, smoking rooms and roof gardens became famed across the country. In April  the business was acquired by the House of Fraser group and in the years following, ious changes took place, both in nameand in ownership. Hourstons Ltd was formed in  by Isaac and Helen Jebreel of Hampstead, London. The store’s Facebook site says: “Hourstonshas been a retail beacon on the high street for generations, everyone has a story or memory in connection with the place” Shoppers shared their memories on its Facebook site this week. Sharon Johnstone said: “My uncle Bob was your restaurant manager years ago. “There was the wee lady in the lt, Santa, and many more lovely memories. “Hourstons will never be forgotten as long as there are mums and grannys still saying, “look at the state of you, I couldn’t dress you in Hourstons window!”Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnFacebookLawsonAyrSocial mediaAyr News

title: hydro power set earn cash
story: NewsHydro power set to earn cash from the River AyrA water-driven turbine is set to generate power from river flowShareByStephen Houston:,  FEB Updated:,  FEB NewsWeve got the power - how the turbine will operate "Get the biggest daily stories by emailSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA cash generating hydro turbine delayed for more than three years seems set to happen at last. The pound million screw will be positioned right on the old mill weir on the River Ayr opposite Ayrshire College. The weir originally drove an old cornmill on the site. Now tens of thousands of pounds a year will be generated by the flow of the river. Updated plans are now being considered by South Ayrshire Council, which is behind the scheme through the local Energy Agency. They show a single archimedes screw turbine at the old Nethermills Weir. Consultants Mann Power Hydro say: “Completion of this project will create a supply of renewable energy into the local distribution network, proposing firstly to sell the majority of output locally to meet the electricity demands of Ayrshire College, where the grid connection will be made. “In mitigation, the project includes a historic improvement to the passage of eels, lampreys and salmon smolts at the weir by the provision of new specialised passes for these species, and also improves upstream and downstream migration for salmon and other fish species. “It will moderate the flows into the existing passes in some conditions, which will make these less challenging. “This will help ameliorate a general problem whereby a weir is a barrier to migration of fish.” It is predicted the turbine - more than  feet in diameter and  feet long - will generate up to  kilowatts per year. The blade will turn at a maximum  revolutions per minute The Energy Agency carried out a study last year to estimate the energy potential passing over the weirs at Nethermills. It is expected the council will pocket pound, a year from selling the power and the scheme would receive a pound, feed-in-tarf. The single four-bladed screw is enough to power  homes. A report said: “With proper maintenance the scheme should continue to generate clean power for many decades after its capital cost has been repaid. “The scheme would provide an eye-catching and interesting landmark in the middle of the town, an emblem of the community’s dedication to the principle of sustainable development. A decision on approval is expected shortly.Like us on FacebookFollow us on TwitterDaily NewsletterTheScottishDailyRecordFollow @Daily_RecordSubscribe to our Daily newsletterEnter emailSubscribeMore OnSouth Ayrshire CouncilAyrAyr NewsEnvironmentScottish rivers

title: staff-absences-at-scottish-borders-council-costing-more-than-3m-a-year
story: STAFF absences at Scottish Borders Council are costing the local authority more than poundm a year, new figures reveal.Over the last three financial years, employees taking sick days have cost the council pound.m, and last year alone pound.m was spent on sick leave.A previous freedom of information request to the council found that Scottish Borders Council loses more than , days to sickness absence each year, with the most common reason for absence being anxiety, depression, or stress.In between  and , employees of the council took , sick days due to mental health issues, an average of , days a year.A spokesperson for SBC said: ldquoThe council remains committed to the health, wellbeing and professional development of all our staff and making sure they feel valued, supported and provided with the right environment, training, skills and knowledge to do their job effectively.ldquoScottish Borders Council continues to work in partnership with our occupational health provider to support employees who are unwell and to assist staff in staying at work or helping them tosooner.ldquoWe also have a helpline which is provided by our occupational health provider and is available  hours a day, seven days a week to provide support and guidance on health issues. An immediate referral is madean employee is absent from work because of stress or mental health issues.ldquoStaff with personal work related stress are supported through the councilrsquos attendance management policy, which recognises the need for a consistent approach to managing absence while also supporting employees. The council offers a range of training opportunities to all staff to aid managing mental health wellbeing.ldquoIt is worth noting that the overall number of days lost to employee sickness has reduced by over  per cent in the last five years, while the number of days lost to staff suffering from anxiety, stress, depression and other mental health issues reduced by almost half in the same period.Scottish Borders Council currently employs , people, meaning each employee takes an average of . sickness day each year.According to the Office for National Statistics, an estimated . million working days were lost due to sickness or injury in the UK in . This is equivalent to . days per worker.This means that Scottish Borders Council employees take more than twice as many sickness days as the average UK worker.Furthermore, the most common reason for sickness absence in the UK is minor illnesses, such as common colds, as opposed to Scottish Borders Council, where the biggest cause of sickness absence, in terms of days lost per year, is mental health problems.

title: dirtpot-improvements-progress-without-delay
